title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Extremely overpriced speaker of just decent sound
author: bobwatts
content: The media could not be loaded. I have always ascribed to the philosophy that if I’m going to listen to something, I require it to reproduce the One True Sound. In other words, as close to the original sound as possible. And I listen to music literally all day, sometimes all night also.Bluetooth speakers by definition are a compromise and will never be a substitute for a Real Sound System, but some manufacturers products perform a lot better than others. And it is an undeniable fact that Bluetooth and wireless speakers are getting far better.In the last four years alone, I have handled, listened to, tested and experienced hundreds of Bluetooth speakers and have written quite a few reviews. I bought a lot of them. Paid money. Some over $500.I don't claim "audiophile" status, but I am extremely discerning in my listening requirements.I will rarely mention competitors' products but might "hint" at something.I have been aware of Ultimate Ears products but have never purchased any, usually because I thought they were priced very high. Although they get good reviews (usually, certainly not always) I just didn't think that such a small speaker could deliver on the promise of "Thundering Bass". Well, they don't.I tried this speaker in every bass trap in my house that usually helps most speakers, and it did improve this speaker marginally. Using the speaker outside was pointless if volume and quality of sound is required.In the case of this speaker, it has 2" drivers, one of each side of the cylindrical case. I am aware that this speaker has two passive radiators, and they are supposed to be "softer" than the Megaboom3 which ostensibly is supposed to improve bass response. I wouldn't expect much bass response from such small drivers, but the manufacturer clearly states "Thundering Bass" in the advertisement, and it is also on the box. (see picture).Not only have I heard smaller speakers with better bass, but I have heard and own many speakers costing far less than this one that outperforms this speaker by quite a large margin.I will say that for such a small speaker the bass response is remarkable, even good. But "Thundering"?Ridiculous.And when cylindrical speakers claim to have "360°" sound, this is usually a falsehood as well. You can definitely hear a difference when one of the two drivers is pointed at you. Assuming that you should keep the volume controls pointed at you means that the very directional high frequency sounds are going off to the sides, away from you. By simply turning the speaker 90° you will hear the difference.I was struck by the look and size of this speaker when I received it so much that I decided to get my 2015 9-year-old first generation Amazon Echo speaker out of storage and compare the units. (this turned out to be a one-hour debacle to get it going again, long story) The two speakers are almost the exact same size.The Megaboom4 definitely had more bass (not by much), but the Echo was a bit brighter and clearer in the sound delivery. (see video) I downloaded the Ultimate Ears ap immediately upon arrival of the speaker and "tuned" it to my liking (which is usually maximum treble and bass, drop the mids slightly for most speakers) so I gave it the best chance of sounding good/great. I also tried the "signature" settings.This speaker connects quickly and stays connected. Controls work well. Speaker has a very nice professional appearance, and the box protects it well during shipment. The box also has a high degree of professionalism in its appearance.I appreciate the lack of silly lights, and the connection "sounds" are not as obnoxious or silly as most speakers, but the turning off sound is very loud.Frankly I would have given this speaker four stars if the manufacturer had not claimed "Thundering Bass". That is an outrageously false claim. This speaker sounds very good for what it is, but for the price, I can buy many better speakers. I actually have.If I had purchased this speaker I would have returned it.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 31, 2024
